content.description: Apparently, this route was established as an easy way to get up top and set topropes for other routes. The 5.7 is moving past the one bolt. Before and after that, it is much easier.The anchors are two hangers, and they are not rap bolts. The best way for the last climber to get down is to rap off different anchors or find the scrambling descent. Rapping off this route's anchors might not kill your rope, but is it worth risking it on a 20' route?
content.location: Far left and of the wall, past the chimney. Look for a dihedral and a single bolt.

content.description: This is a wide crack, but there are also plenty of face holds to use. If you want to plug gear in limestone, here you go. The rock seems reasonably good until the crack ends. You can protect the finish, but it's choss.
content.protection: The crack will take large cams.
content.location: Obvious large crack. You can't miss it, especially with the picture here. Bolted anchors up top.

content.description: Slabby moves with a nice flake hold up high.
content.protection: Two bolt hangers on the top. Bring anchor building material to extend past the ledge.
content.location: Shares anchors with The Path of the Weekend Warrior.  This route stays right.

content.description: Climb through a low roof start and follow a thin crack to an easier finish. Lots of choss on this section of the wall.
content.protection: Hangers up top for TR anchors. Shares anchors with Pwnership.
content.location: Maybe 10-15 yards right of the Jodi Adair show, the only bolted route on this section of the wall, locate a large tree growing close to the wall. Look for the thin crack left of a low mini-roof.

content.description: Pull the low mini-roof, move up and right to a ledge, and then finish on easier ground.
content.protection: Two hangers up top for TR anchors. Shares anchors with Shit Happens.
content.location: Maybe 10-15 yards right of the Jodi Adair show, the only bolted route on this section of the wall, locate a large tree growing close to the wall. Look for the low mini-roof.

content.description: Fun starting move pulling up to a rail.  Same slab top out as the two routes to the left.
content.protection: Two anchors, no quick links.  Shared with Honesty is the Best Policy and Bleeding Heart Conservative.
content.location: Right side of bulge. Start with left hand in one of the three vertical pockets.

content.description: Begin at the triangular-shaped hueco just left of the arete. Traverse left to another hueco (awkward because both holds are reachable from the ground for many people) and then go up, staying right of the bolt line.
content.protection: Hangers for TR anchors. Using just quickdraws will cause rope drag and wear on the rock and rope.
content.location: Just to the right of the Jodi Adair Show, the only bolted route on the creek-facing wall. The routes share anchors.

climbs.name: The Path of the Weekend Warrior

content.description: Slabby delicate climbing with a few nice monos.
content.protection: Two bolt hangers on the top. Bring anchor building material to extend past the ledge.
content.location: Shares anchors with Staunch Liberal.  This route stays left.

content.description:
The crux, if there is one, might be the start. Various types of jams are possible on this short route.

 Like other routes at Philosophy Wall, it has anchors that can be accessed from scrambling up top, but this one will go on gear, too. Remember that it's limestone.
content.protection: Nuts, tricams, and it will take cams up to a 6 if you want to haul one out. Two bolted anchors.
content.location: In the right-center section of the wall, find an off-width crack leading to anchors below a roof.

content.description: A short, fun sport route that feels easier than the 5.7 grade. I'd call it 5.4 or 5.5, but I like to respect the FA and publish a route at his suggested grade.
content.protection: 3 bolts. Bolted anchors. The anchors are set back a bit. Use long slings or a cordelette to make a TR anchor.
content.location:
Look for a cave-like feature near the right-center portion of the wall. The route is just right of the cave and is the only bolted route in sight.

 You can scramble up top way to the right to set a TR if you prefer.

content.description: Crux is pulling off the ground. Be ready to clean the route and beware of holly leaves.
content.location: Start on the left side of the bulge slightly right of the black streak with left hand in noticeable three-finger pocket with thumb hold.

content.description: Fun short route with big moves on good holds.  Harder if you don’t have good reach.
content.protection: Two anchors, no quick links. Located on caprock seven feet away from more visible anchors on cliff face.
content.location: Start at the big mouth-shaped hueco.

content.description: Pull up on good pockets and make a slab move or two and then you’re at the top.
content.protection: Anchors at the top, no quick links, shared with Unnamed Crack

content.description: Climb the right-facing edge a few feet right of a huge triangular hueco. Go up and left, finishing on Hedonism, which shares anchors. One-move wonder.
content.location: 20 yards or so to the right of the Jodi Adair Show, the only bolted route on this part of the wall, find a huge triangular hueco above a low roof. The climb starts on the edge to the right of the hueco.

content.description: Crux is down low on thin crimps that lead to a slopery slab section.  Holds are more positive at the top.
content.protection: Two bolt hangers on the top.  Bring anchor building material to extend past the ledge.
content.location: Just left of the large access crack.  This route shares anchors with Buddhism. Buddhism is an easier climb slightly to the left.

content.description: Squeezed in route with unique holds.
content.protection: Two anchors, no quick links. Shared with Honesty is the Best Policy and Pinko Commie.
content.location: Just to the right of Honesty is the Best Policy on the left side of the bulge.

content.description:
If The Matrix is not the least-used and least-appreciated spot at North Shore, this is. With only two or three bolted routes and a few trad routes on limestone and lots of toprope routes, this place gets little attention.

 The local guidebook lists over 30 toprope routes from 5.6 to 5.11d. There are numerous bolted anchors up top. Some require long slings or some cord instead of just quickdraws. Many routes share anchors.

 To get to the top, lead a bolted route or scramble up 3rd class terrain off to the right.
